questions.text: A child was brought with fever and stridor. The X-ray of the neck showed the following image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child presents with fever and inspiratory stridor, and the X-ray shows the "steeple sign", a radiologic feature of Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis (ALTB), also known as croup.

Croup typically affects children between 6 months and 5 years of age.

It is usually viral in origin, most commonly caused by parainfluenza virus.

Clinical features include:

  • Barking/seal-like cough
  • Low-grade fever
  • Nasal congestion and rhinorrhea (prodromal phase)
  • Inspiratory stridor (worsens with agitation or crying) - d/t inflammatory narrowing of larynx
  • Wheeze - d/t inflammatory narrowing of trachea and bronchi

X-ray finding:

  • Steeple sign = subglottic narrowing of the trachea on frontal neck X-ray

Explanation of Other Options:

Acute Epiglottitis (Option A):

Presents with drooling, high fever, toxic appearance, and tripod positioning. Stridor is late. X-ray shows "thumb sign", not steeple sign.

Thumb sign

Foreign body aspiration (Option C):

Sudden onset, often during eating/play, with unilateral wheeze, cough, or choking, without fever. X-ray may show localized hyperinflation or air trapping, or may be normal if the foreign body is radiolucent.

Laryngomalacia (Option D):

Most common congenital cause of stridor, appearing within the first few weeks of life. Stridor is inspiratory, worse on supine position or feeding, and improves when prone.

Flexible laryngoscopy shows an omega-shaped epiglottis, which collapses during inspiration. X-ray is typically normal, and fever is absent.

questions.text: Staccato paroxysms of cough are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Staccato cough is defined as a rapid series of short coughs with inspirations between each cough sound (Staccato means an inspiration after each cough). It is a classic feature of neonatal or infantile Chlamydia trachomatis infection, especially in the absence of fever.

This cough is paroxysmal and persistent but non-whooping, differentiating it from pertussis. The pattern arises from the involvement of the lower respiratory tract and irritation of airways in infants, who are unable to effectively expectorate.

Causes of staccato or paroxysmal cough include:

  • Pertussis (with or without post-tussive vomiting)
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Chlamydia trachomatis infection
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Foreign body aspiration

Explanation of other options:

Allergic sinusitis (Option A): While allergic rhinosinusitis may cause post-nasal drip and throat clearing, it does not cause paroxysmal or staccato cough.

Tracheitis (Option B): Bacterial tracheitis presents with barking cough, toxic appearance, and respiratory distress, but not a staccato pattern.

Psychogenic cough (Option C): Psychogenic cough often has a habitual, honking, or dry character and is absent during sleep. It lacks the structured paroxysmal staccato pattern.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was diagnosed to have pneumonia. Which among the following shall be the therapy of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In school-aged children, the most common cause of pneumonia is Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • For outpatient management, when pneumoniae or Chlamydophila pneumoniae is suspected, a macrolide antibiotic is preferred.
  • Azithromycin is the first-line macrolide of choice.
  • Alternatives include:
    • Clarithromycin
    • Doxycycline (only if child is 8 years or older)
  • In adolescents, respiratory fluoroquinolones (e.g., levofloxacin, moxifloxacin) may be used if there are contraindications to other agents.

Explanation of other options:

Amoxicillin (Option B): Amoxicillin is first-line for bacterial CAP in preschool children, where Streptococcus pneumoniae is more common. It does not cover atypical organisms like Mycoplasma.

Doxycycline (Option C): Though effective against Mycoplasma pneumoniae, doxycycline is generally avoided in children under 8 years due to the risk of permanent teeth discoloration. It can be considered in adolescents if macrolides are contraindicated.

Cefixime (Option D): Cefixime is a third-generation oral cephalosporin used for some bacterial infections, but it has limited activity against atypical organisms such as M. pneumoniae.

questions.text: A child was diagnosed with severe pneumonia and started on intravenous antibiotics. On day 5 of illness, the chest X-ray shown below was obtained due to persistent respiratory distress. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The chest X-ray shows a well-defined, thin-walled, air-filled cyst in the lung parenchyma, consistent with a pneumatocele.

  • Pneumatoceles are a known complication of Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia in children.
  • Although Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism, other rare pathogens include Streptococci, Haemophilus influenzae, and Klebsiella pneumoniae.

Pneumatoceles are typically self-resolving, and most patients improve with:

  • Supportive care, and
  • Antibiotics directed at the underlying infection.

Routine intervention is not necessary unless:

  • The pneumatocele becomes infected,
  • Causes respiratory compromise, or
  • Ruptures, leading to pneumothorax.

Thus, in a clinically stable child, observation and supportive care is the most appropriate next step.

Explanation of other options:

ECMO (Option A): Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) is reserved for life-threatening respiratory failure refractory to conventional ventilation. This child is not in that category.

Surgical bullectomy (Option C): Surgery is reserved for persistent, enlarging, or complicated pneumatoceles that don't resolve with conservative therapy.

Percutaneous aspiration (Option D): This is not routinely indicated in uncomplicated pneumatocele. May be considered only if it evolves into a tension cyst or becomes infected/abscessed.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of pneumonia in an HIV-positive child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is the most common cause of pneumonia in HIV-infected children, particularly in those with severe immunosuppression (CD4 < 200 cells/mm³).

  • Children typically present with progressive respiratory distress, dry cough, fever, and hypoxemia, often without significant auscultatory findings. Chest X-ray classically shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates, without hilar lymphadenopathy or consolidation.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstration of organisms in induced sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL), or respiratory secretions, typically using Giemsa or silver staining, or PCR.
  • Drug of choice: IV Cotrimoxazole (TMP-SMX) for 21 days
  • Adjunctive steroids are added when PaOâ‚‚ < 70 mmHg or A-a gradient > 30 mmHg, to reduce inflammatory lung injury
  • PJP often presents early in infancy in vertically infected children, making prophylaxis with cotrimoxazole essential in those with low CD4 counts.

Explanation of other options:

Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare (Option A): Occurs in advanced HIV, more often presents with disseminated disease (fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly) rather than isolated pneumonia in children.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): While it can cause bacterial pneumonia in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised children, it is not the most common cause in HIV-infected children.

Aspergillus fumigatus (Option C): Primarily causes invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in severely neutropenic or immunosuppressed patients, but it is much less common in HIV-infected children than PJP.

questions.text: The most appropriate investigation in infants with acute bronchiolitis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acute bronchiolitis is a clinical diagnosis, typically made in infants presenting with coryzal symptoms followed by wheeze, tachypnea, crepitations, and respiratory distress. Routine investigations are not necessary in most cases.

  • On clinical examination, no other findings can be found except the infant having tachypnoea, mild recession and equal air entrywith marked expiratory wheezes and crepitation.
  • There is no need to do a chest X-ray or NPA (Nasopharyngeal aspirate)
  • NPA (Nasopharyngeal aspirate) is indicated in children with chronic lung disease, congenital heart disease and immunocompromised, progressing neurological problems.
  • ABG is reserved for infants with signs of impending respiratory failure, altered mental status, or hypoxemia despite oxygen therapy.

questions.text: A child with noisy breathing was found to have stridor on examination. His laryngoscopic finding is as shown below. What is the likely type of stridor in this child?
questions.solution:
The child is having laryngomalacia since he has stridor & laryngoscopy showing the typical omega-epiglottis.

  • In Laryngomalacia, supraglottic part of the larynx is involved, and thus most patients have episodic or intermittent inspiratory stridor.
  • Remember the concept
    • Supraglottic Obstruction: Inspiratory Stridor is present
    • Infraglottic or Trachel Obstruction: Biphasic Stridor is present

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition

choices.text: Perform DNA testing for CFTR gene mutations
Perform a pH probe test for gastroesophageal reflux
Reassure parents that he does not have CF
Place him on a high-calorie, high-protein diet

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has a history of recurrent sinusitis and multiple episodes of pneumonia. You suspect cystic fibrosis and order a sweat chloride test. The sweat electrolyte test result is within the normal range. What is your next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history of recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections, especially recurrent sinusitis and pneumonia, strongly suggests cystic fibrosis (CF).

  • While the sweat chloride test is the first-line diagnostic test, false-negative results can occur, particularly in patients with certain mild or atypical mutations.
  • In such cases, the next best step is DNA analysis to detect CFTR gene mutations.
  • Genetic testing can identify over 2000 known mutations, and detecting two disease-causing mutations confirms the diagnosis even if the sweat chloride level is normal or borderline.
  • This step is crucial before ruling out CF, as early diagnosis is essential for initiating appropriate management including nutritional support, pulmonary therapy, and infection-control measures.

Explanation of other options:

Perform a pH probe test for gastroesophageal reflux (Option B): While GERD can coexist with CF, it is not the next diagnostic step in evaluating suspected CF. It does not help confirm or rule out CF.

Reassure parents that he does not have CF (Option C): A normal sweat test does not exclude CF. Clinical features must guide further evaluation. Reassurance without further testing would be inappropriate.

Place him on a high-calorie, high-protein diet (Option D): Nutritional support is essential after a diagnosis of CF is confirmed. It is not a diagnostic or confirmatory step.

questions.text: Congenital absence of seminal vesicles and vas deferens is seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is associated with a high prevalence of male infertility due to congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD), a condition resulting from abnormal development of the Wolffian duct structures, including the vas deferens and seminal vesicles. More than 95% of males with CF are azoospermic, though they often have normal sexual function and normal spermatogenesis within the testes.

CBAVD is frequently the only presenting feature in otherwise healthy men and may even be seen in males with mild or atypical CFTR mutations.

In females with cystic fibrosis, fertility is reduced, mainly due to thick cervical mucus, but reproductive anatomy is usually intact.

Explanation of other options:

Klinefelter syndrome (Option B): Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) is associated with small, firm testes, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, and impaired spermatogenesis, but vas deferens and seminal vesicles are present.

Kallmann syndrome (Option C): Kallmann syndrome is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia due to GnRH deficiency, but the anatomical structures of the reproductive tract are usually intact.

Chromosomal microdeletion (Option D): Y-chromosome microdeletions (especially AZF regions) are associated with spermatogenic failure, but they do not cause absence of vas deferens or seminal vesicles.

questions.text: A child has been recently diagnosed with cystic fibrosis, and his gene analysis report revealed a deletion of the phenylalanine residue at position 508. What class of mutation does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7, which codes for a chloride channel.

  • The ΔF508 (delF508) mutation, the most common mutation in CF worldwide, results in the deletion of a phenylalanine residue at position 508.
  • This mutation leads to misfolding of the CFTR protein, which is then degraded in the endoplasmic reticulum, preventing it from reaching the cell surface.
  • This mutation falls under Class II CFTR mutations, characterized by defective protein processing and trafficking.

Classification of CFTR Mutations:

questions.text: All of the following new molecular agents are CFTR correctors except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Regulator (CFTR) Modulators are drugs that improve the function of the defective CFTR protein in cystic fibrosis. These agents are classified into two main types based on their mechanism of action:

  • CFTR Correctors: These drugs improve processing and trafficking of CFTR protein to the cell surface. They are most effective in Class II mutations, such as the ΔF508 (Del508Phe) mutation.
    Examples: Lumacaftor, Tezacaftor, Elexacaftor (Options A, B & C ruled out)
  • CFTR Potentiators: These drugs enhance the function of already-present CFTR proteins at the cell surface by increasing channel opening probability. They are primarily effective in Class III mutations, like G551D.
    Example: Ivacaftor

Note: Many commercial preparations combine both category of drugs to have a synergistic action.

questions.text: Nasal nitric oxide measurement is useful to screen for which among the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD) is a rare, genetically inherited disorder characterized by impaired function of motile cilia lining the respiratory tract, leading to chronic respiratory symptoms, sinusitis, otitis media, and often situs inversus.

A highly useful, non-invasive screening test for PCD is nasal nitric oxide (nNO) measurement, which is typically markedly reduced in affected individuals.

  • This test is currently recommended for children aged ≥5 years and adults with unexplained recurrent respiratory symptoms.
  • nNO values <77 nL/min on two separate occasions, more than 2 months apart, with cystic fibrosis excluded, are strongly suggestive of PCD.

The test is preferred because it is simple, reproducible, and non-invasive, although not diagnostic by itself. Diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing or ciliary ultrastructure analysis (e.g., via electron microscopy).

Explanation of other options:

Exercise-induced asthma (Option A): Diagnosis is based on spirometry with exercise challenge or bronchoprovocation testing. Nasal nitric oxide is not used in its evaluation.

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) (Option C): ABPA is diagnosed using IgE levels, eosinophil count, chest imaging, and Aspergillus-specific antibodies, not nasal NO.

Interstitial Lung Disease (Option D): ILD diagnosis involves high-resolution CT, lung biopsy, and pulmonary function tests. nNO has no role in its screening or diagnosis.

questions.text: Kartagener Syndrome is characterized by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kartagener Syndrome is a clinical subset of Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia and is classically defined by a triad of:

  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Situs inversus

This occurs due to defective motility of cilia, leading to impaired mucociliary clearance. Approximately 50% of patients with PCD have situs inversus, making the syndrome eponymously associated with this triad.

Differential pulses (e.g., radiofemoral delay) are not a feature of Kartagener Syndrome and are typically seen in aortic coarctation, a cardiovascular anomaly unrelated to ciliary dysfunction.

questions.text: An infant presented with progressive respiratory distress. The chest X-ray was taken (image shown below). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and imaging are consistent with congenital lobar emphysema (CLE), a rare congenital anomaly characterized by hyperinflation of a pulmonary lobe, most commonly the left upper lobe, due to a defect in bronchial cartilage leading to air trapping.

Congenital lobar emphysema (CLE):

  • Clinical manifestations usually become apparent in the neonatal period but are delayed for as long as 5-6 yr in 5% of patients.
  • Clinical signs range from mild tachypnea and wheeze to severe dyspnea with cyanosis.
  • CLE can affect one or more lobes; it affects the upper and middle lobes, and the left upper lobe is the most common site.
  • The affected lobe becomes overdistended and non-functional. Ipsilateral normal lung may undergo atelectasis due to compression.
  • Withfurther distention, the mediastinum is shifted to the contralateral side, with impaired function seen as well.
  • An aradiolucent lobe and a mediastinal shift are often revealed by radiographic examination.

Hyperaeration of the left upper lobe (black arrow) manifest by hyperlucency.

The left lower lobe is compressed by the over-expanded upper lobe (white arrow).

The expanded lung displaces the mediastinum to the right (red arrow).

Explanation of other options:

Swyer-James Syndrome (Option A): This is a post-infectious unilateral hyperlucent lung syndrome typically diagnosed in older children or adolescents, not infants. It results from obliterative bronchiolitis after a viral infection (e.g., adenovirus).

Overexpansion and hyperlucency

Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) (Option B): CPAM usually presents as a cystic lesion on imaging. It may show air-fluid levels, multiple cysts, or a mass effect, but not typically lobar hyperinflation as in CLE.

Multiloculated cystic lesion in right hemithorax with marked mediastinal shift to the left

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (Option D): CDH usually presents with bowel loops in the thoracic cavity, mediastinal shift, and scaphoid abdomen. It is diagnosed antenatally or shortly after birth and doesn't show isolated lobar hyperinflation.

questions.text: An adolescent 16-year-old boy has been having multiple attacks of rhinosinusitis since birth. At the age of 10 years, he had productive cough with hemoptysis, and HRCT revealed cystic spaces with honeycombing which required antibiotics and chest physiotherapy. There was no situs inversus. The treating doctor advised a semen analysis to check for sperm count. What syndrome is the doctor most likely considering?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture is suggestive of recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections (rhinosinusitis, bronchiectasis) with preserved situs and a concern for male infertility, prompting semen analysis. These features together point towards Young Syndrome.

Young Syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by the triad of:

  • Chronic sinusitis, nasal polyps
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Obstructive azoospermia (infertility due to epididymal obstruction)

The seminal fluid in Young syndrome is typically thick, viscous, and lipid-rich, which leads to impaired sperm transport.

Unlike Kartagener syndrome, Young syndrome does not involve situs inversus, and primary ciliary dyskinesia is not necessarily present.

Explanation of other options:

Kartagener Syndrome (Option A): Though Kartagener syndrome also presents with bronchiectasis and sinusitis, it is classically associated with situs inversus due to primary ciliary dyskinesia. The absence of situs inversus here makes this less likely.

Cystic Fibrosis (Option C): CF can cause bronchiectasis and infertility, but it typically presents with failure to thrive, pancreatic insufficiency, and other systemic manifestations. The absence of those findings, and normal lung function apart from bronchiectasis, make CF unlikely.

Job Syndrome (Option D): Job syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome) includes eczema, recurrent skin and lung infections, eosinophilia, and elevated IgE levels. Infertility is not a classic feature of this syndrome.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539867/

choices.text: Absence of any specific organ involvement

questions.text: All are true regarding hypereosinophilic syndrome in children except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES) is a heterogeneous group of disorders defined by persistently elevated absolute eosinophil count (AEC ≥1500 cells/µL) either:

  • persisting for ≥6 months, (Options A & B ruled out)
  • on ≥2 occasions, or
  • with histologic evidence of tissue eosinophilia,

AND meeting both of the following criteria:

  1. No identifiable secondary cause of eosinophilia,
  2. Evidence of organ dysfunction or damage caused by eosinophils.

Organ systems commonly involved include pulmonary, cardiac, neurologic, cutaneous, GI, and serosal sites.
The most serious complication is eosinophilic endomyocardial disease, which can lead to heart failure from thrombosis and fibrosis.

Treatment:

  • First-line therapy is corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone). (Option D ruled out)
  • In PDGFRA fusion-positive cases, imatinib mesylate is curative.

Other agents include hydroxyurea, interferon-α, or mepolizumab (anti-IL-5 mAb) in steroid-refractory patients.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presents with an episode of choking and cyanosis. On examination, air entry is reduced on the left side of the chest. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of sudden onset choking and cyanosis, along with reduced air entry, strongly suggests foreign body aspiration (FBA), a pediatric emergency.

The first step in management is a Chest X-ray to evaluate for signs like unilateral hyperinflation, atelectasis, or visible foreign body. However, Chest X-ray may be normal in up to 30-50% of cases.

Rigid bronchoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic, and should follow the imaging promptly in a stable child with high suspicion of FBA. It helps locate and remove the foreign body.

CECT chest is not preferred initially due to:

  • Unnecessary radiation exposure
  • Delay in management
  • Limited added value if bronchoscopy is planned

There is no evidence of pleural pathology or fluid, hence ICD (intercostal drain) is not indicated.

Coin in esophagus

choices.text: Increase in FEV1 >12% after salbutamol inhalation
Day and night variation of FEV1 >15%

questions.text: All the following pulmonary function test (PFT) findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except:
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Asthma is a reversible obstructive airway disorder, and pulmonary function tests (PFTs) play a critical role in its diagnosis. The key diagnostic parameters involve spirometry with bronchodilator response, exercise challenge, and daily monitoring of peak expiratory flow or FEV1.

The following PFT criteria support a diagnosis of asthma:

  • Spirometry (in clinic):
    • Airflow limitation:
      • Low FEV1 (relative to percentage of predicted norms)
      • FEV1: FVC ratio <0.80 (Option B ruled out)
    • Bronchodilator response (to inhaled β-agonist):Improvement in FEV1 ≥12% and ≥200 mL (Option A ruled out)
    • Exercise challenge: Worsening in FEV1 ≥15% (Option C ruled out)
    • Daily peak flow or FEV1 monitoring: day to day and/or A.M.-to-P.M. variation ≥20%

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is suspected to have an asthma-like illness, and inhalation therapy is planned. Which of the following devices is appropriate for use in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

In infants and young children, the preferred method for inhaled drug delivery is a metered dose inhaler (MDI) with a spacer and face mask. This setup compensates for poor hand-breath coordination and ensures effective drug delivery to the lungs.

Children under 2-3 years of age cannot reliably coordinate inhalation or form a tight seal around a mouthpiece. The face mask provides a proper seal over the mouth and nose, ensuring adequate medication delivery.

MDIs with spacers minimize oropharyngeal deposition and allow efficient drug deposition in the lower airways without requiring coordination between actuation and inhalation, making them ideal for infants.

Device selection based on age:

  • <4 years: MDI + Spacer + Face Mask (Options A & B ruled out)
  • 4-12 years: MDI + Spacer
  • >12 years: MDI alone (spacer optional)

Dry Powder Inhalers (DPIs) require high inspiratory flow and are not suitable for infants or toddlers. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Eczema is a major risk factor for persistent asthma
Low birth weight is an identifiable factor for the persistence of childhood asthma
Immunization may help reduce the likelihood of asthma development
10% of preschool children who have recurrent cough & wheeze will have persistent asthma later on

questions.text: Regarding persistent asthma in children, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The development of persistent asthma in children has been associated with identifiable major and minor risk factors.

Early Childhood Risk Factors for Persistent Asthma:

Major risk factors include:

  • Parental history of asthma
  • Eczema (atopic dermatitis)
  • Sensitization to inhalant allergens

Minor risk factors include:

  • Allergic rhinitis
  • Wheezing apart from colds
  • ≥4% peripheral blood eosinophils
  • Sensitization to food allergens
  • Severe LRTI (e.g., pneumonia, bronchiolitis requiring hospitalization)
  • Male gender (Option B ruled out)
  • Low birthweight
  • Environmental tobacco smoke exposure
  • Reduced lung function at birth
  • Formula feeding rather than breastfeeding

About one-third (33%) of preschool children who experience recurrent wheezing and cough go on to develop persistent asthma in later childhood. The remaining two-thirds generally show improvement with age. (Option D ruled out)

There is no conclusive evidence that routine immunization play a role in preventing persistent asthma. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with a strong family history of bronchial asthma has multiple episodes of wheeze and cough whenever he plays or runs. He is diagnosed with exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. What shall be the prophylaxis of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB) is a transient narrowing of the lower airways that occurs during or after exercise, especially in children with underlying asthma.

According to the GINA 2023 guidelines, daily inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) like budesonide are the prophylaxis of choice in children with recurrent EIB, especially when associated with underlying asthma symptoms or family history, as in this case. ICS not only prevent EIB but also treat the underlying airway inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

Inhaled Salbutamol (Option B): Short-acting β2 agonists (SABA) like salbutamol can be used 15–30 minutes before exercise for short-term prevention of EIB. However, for regular prophylaxis, it is not ideal due to the risk of tolerance and lack of anti-inflammatory effect.

Inhaled Salmeterol (Option C): Long-acting β2 agonists (LABA) like salmeterol may reduce EIB temporarily but develop rapid tolerance with regular use and must never be used without concurrent ICS, due to risk of asthma-related death.

Oral Montelukast (Option D): Leukotriene receptor antagonists like Montelukast have variable and modest efficacy in EIB. They may help in some patients but are not first-line for prophylaxis.

Reference: GINA-2023-Full-report-23_07_06-WMS.pdf
